awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Time-Resolved Multi-Pulse Spectroscopy of Solvated Aza-Aromatics
awd_abstract_narration:
Molecules that can absorb light and use the energy to drive chemical reactions are potentially interesting for new technologies in energy storage, water treatment, and industrial chemical production. However, understanding and controlling these processes is challenging because energy is generally expended quickly but stored slowly. For example, filming a speeding bullet (energy flow) poses different challenges than filming a flower growing (energy storage). In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Cody W. Schlenker of the University of Washington (UW) is using advanced laser techniques to provide fundamental understanding of how light absorption drives chemical reactions, two processes with rates as different as the velocity of a speeding bullet and the growth of a flower. The scientific knowledge gleaned from this project has the potential to improve sunlight-to-fuel conversions, solar water decontamination, and possibly even new avenues for light-driven industrial chemical production. Professor Schlenker's Research-Integrated Science Education (RISE) Program focusses on helping to equip low-income and potential first-generation college students with the tools needed to apply to college, succeed in STEM majors, and enter the STEM workforce. The group integrates research and education to develop new peer-generated science tutorials presented by students from the most ethnically and culturally diverse public high-schools in Washington State (e.g. Chief Sealth High School in Southern West Seattle through a partnership with the UW's Math & Science Upward Bound program). One example product of the RISE Program: Step-by-step, peer-led-learning video science experiments are distributed freely on a RISE-dedicated YouTube channel. The research group also leverages existing UW resources, for example, through a partnership with the UW Clean Energy Institute. Organic photochemistry may lay the conceptual groundwork for new research in the field of solar water splitting. Cheap and scalable solar hydrogen could positively impact energy and food sustainability, since ammonia fertilizer production is resource intensive.

The scientific objective of this project is to understand the role of inter-molecular excited states in the photochemistry of hydrogen-bonded molecular complexes. This research is focused particularly on understanding how nitrogen-containing molecules known as azaarenes photochemically react by removing hydrogen atoms from water and alcohols. To achieve this goal, the research team uses spectroscopic and electrochemical signals associated with transient, photogenerated, excited-states and free radicals. The population of these species are monitored as a function of the temporal delay between an initial ultrafast visible laser pulse (pump) and a subsequent infrared pulse (push) using transient absorption, photoluminescence, and electrical current detection. This approach is notable because it has the potential to extract ultrafast time information from the relative yields of much slower chemical reactions. Azaarenes play critical roles in photosynthetic assemblies, DNA photo-protection, photo-stabilization of industrial pigments, and they are common chromophores in renewable energy research focused on proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET). In these capacities, azaarenes can hydrogen-bond with hydroxyl groups. These hydrogen bonding interactions often alter the chromophore's photophysics and photochemical reactivity in seemingly unintuitive ways. The critical mechanistic links between the branching ratio among ultrafast photophysical pathways and the much slower subsequent photochemical reactions of azaarene molecules may constitute a step forward. Broader impacts of this work include potential societal benefits resulting from clarifying whether inter-molecular electronic excited-states that arise from hydrogen bonding interactions serve as a chemical gateway to photon-initiated reactions. Additionally, this project provides training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, integrating research concepts into public engagement activities for science outreach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The mutual motion of positively charge protons and negatively charged electrons, termed “Proton-Coupled Electron Transfer” (PCET), is critically important in many biological processes, such as respiration, and industrial applications, such hydrogen peroxide production. Nature exploits PCET during photosynthesis to store energy from the sun. However, natural photosynthesis is relatively slow and inefficient, on the order of a few percent depending on the species. There is significant interest in designing new materials that could support artificial photosynthesis. The goal would be to efficiently store the energy from the sun within the bonds of synthetic chemical fuels for power at night or later in the year when sunlight is less available. One of the factors that limits development of globally scalable artificial photosynthesis is our incomplete understanding of how light can be used to coax earth-abundant materials into running PCET reactions that suit our needs.

Work in the Schlenker Lab at the University of Washington funded by this NSF Division of Chemistry award revealed thought-provoking new insight into the photochemistry of polymeric materials comprising earth-abundant carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and hydrogen, as well as derivatives of the main molecular subunit of these polymers, called heptazine (Hz). Using sophisticated measurement tools to monitor how light interacts with molecules and advanced computational analysis programs, we observed that Hz derivatives can drive PCET reactions that strip electrons and protons from water and alcohols, processes which are of interest for understanding how sunlight could be used to split water into its elemental components, hydrogen (a potential fuel) and oxygen. This work revealed that the PCET photochemistry of these complexes is influenced by intermolecular mixing of non-bonding molecular orbitals of each component. We demonstrated the ability to control the photochemistry of Hz derivatives using extremely precise sequences of very brief pulses of laser light. Our results indicate that different photochemical reaction pathways can be predictably manipulated with the right sequence of laser pulses, which was an avidly sought achievement in the field of photochemistry at the time of our initial report. Subsequently, we were able to use optical laser pulse sequences to initiate a reaction cycle wherein photoexcited Hz molecules strip hydrogen atoms from hydrogen atom donors and liberate them at a precise time. This mechanistic study allowed us to infer the identity of potential precursors to hydrogen gas generation in possible future photocatalytic cycles for solar energy storage. Work funded by this award also revealed that Hz derivatives exhibit an extremely rare inversion in the energy ordering (EST) of their lowest-energy electronic excited states with different orientations in intrinsic electron angular momentum vectors. This finding demonstrates a violation of the simple angular momentum guidelines that are typically taught in freshman chemistry courses, called Hund's multiplicity rules. Exploiting this unique inverted EST character has obvious implications for transformational discoveries in organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) for energy-saving solid-state lighting technologies and various emerging photovoltaic device platforms for solar energy harvesting. Harnessing this inverted EST, paired with light-driven intermolecular PCET reactions, may also enable future molecular transformations relevant for applications ranging from solar energy storage to new classes of light-powered catalysts for pharmaceutical development to additive manufacturing. These results, which are described in a series of eight peer-reviewed publications supported by this award, help to explain how light-absorbing materials can engage in PCET photochemical reactions and set the stage for future efforts aimed at designing new materials to drive these processes more efficiently. 

This project also supported workforce development by providing cross-disciplinary training for a postdoctoral scholar, several graduate and undergraduate students, and supported the primary doctoral work for three students that graduated with their PhDs. Additional outcomes related to our Research Integrated Science Education (RISE) Program, were the development and deployment of our “Electrochemical Chameleon” laboratory module which we crafted to convey the science water splitting to produce hydrogen and oxygen and which we posted to the University of Washington Clean Energy Institute’s (CEI) educational lesson plans website: https://www.cei.washington.edu/lesson-plans/electrochemical-chameleon, where it can be downloaded and utilized by students, instructors, and outreach coordinators free of charge. This laboratory module also served as the basis for three-day summer RISE workshops that we hosted in partnership with UW Math Science Updward Bound for Seattle area high school students and other student groups. Throughout the life of this award, researchers involved with the project conducted outreach & community engagement events with multiple Puget Sound area schools, including Chief Sealth High School in Southern West Seattle, Tesla High School in Redmond, White Center Heights Elementary School, Cascade Middle School, Hazel Wolf K-8, Renton High School, Einstein Middle School in Shoreline, Edmond Heights K-12, Newport High School in Bellevue, Kentwood High School in Convington, Seattle Waldorf High School, Highline High School, and others in western Washington state.


Last Modified: 10/15/2024
Modified by: Cody W Schlenker
